title: Landmark Israel-Egypt Energy Alliance Hits Snags
text:
Israel’s energy minister Yuval Steinitz, left, next to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other officials, discussed the development of a natural gas platform off Israel’s Mediterranean coast in January.

CAIRO—A landmark 2018 natural-gas deal between Israel and Egypt faces legal challenges and concerns about security threats from Islamic State, casting uncertainty over a pact hailed as a sign of deepening ties between the two countries.

Egypt was supposed to begin importing Israeli gas in March as a part of the $15 billion deal, providing an international outlet for Israel’s burgeoning fossil-fuel business. The accord was also meant to mark a thaw in decades of cool relations between the two neighbors.

But the gas never started flowing as complications arose surrounding the pipeline connecting the two countries and other aspects of the deal. Israeli officials blame bureaucratic setbacks at home for the delay and say the project could start as early as January. Egyptian officials didn’t respond to requests for comment.

A man passes by the site of a militant attack on a gas pipeline outside Egypt’s northern Sinai town of Al Arish in 2012. Photo: Agence France Presse/Getty Images

The delays have slowed Egypt’s plans to become an export hub for vast new natural-gas reserves discovered in the eastern Mediterranean in recent years. Cairo aims to liquefy Israeli and other natural gas and re-export it to Europe or sell it domestically.

Analysts and people close to the project point to other obstacles, including security concerns.

Troubled Link Israel and Egypt plan to revive use of an existing natural-gas pipeline between the two countries whose overland portion in the Sinai Desert has been attacked by militants. EMG* subsea pipeline GASCO† pipeline SYRIA Mediterranean Sea Ashkelon Port Said ISRAEL EGYPT Al Arish SINAI DESERT JORDAN 50 miles 50 km

The gas is supposed to flow over the previously built pipeline between Israel and Egypt across part of the Mediterranean Sea and the Sinai Peninsula, where Islamic State’s Egyptian branch has been reasserting itself in recent months. The group claims to have killed more than 300 people in Egypt during the first half of 2019, including numerous attacks on military convoys in North Sinai.

“If they can’t protect themselves and their own infrastructure, it will be a struggle for them to protect this gas-line infrastructure,” said Zack Gold, an expert on the Sinai insurgency at CNA, a security consulting firm that works with the U.S. government.

Security forces and other mourners carried a coffin containing the body of an Egyptian military officer killed in a clash with militants in North Sinai, during his funeral in Cairo in February. Photo: Mohamed Abd El Ghany/REUTERS

A lawsuit further clouds Cairo’s ability to sell the politically sensitive deal to an Egyptian public deeply suspicious of Israel.

A Thai company is suing Egypt’s government for $1 billion in damages stemming from a previous gas deal with Israel that fell apart after militants attacked the pipeline, forcing Egypt to shut it down in 2012, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS How important is it for Israel and Egypt to find ways to do business together? Join the conversation below.

Thailand’s state-owned PTT Energy Resources Co., a stakeholder in the pipeline operator, Eastern Mediterranean Gas Co., is suing Egypt in a Cairo court, saying it was deprived of revenue when the gas stopped flowing. The lawsuit names Egyptian President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi, other Egyptian officials, and Egypt’s state oil-and-gas companies. A trial is set to begin on Tuesday.

The suit could result in years of litigation, drawing continued attention to the collapse of the previous gas deal. In that agreement, Egypt agreed in 2005 to sell $2.5 billion worth of gas to Israel over the same pipeline.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi is named in a Thai lawsuit seeking damages for a failed Egyptian-Israeli gas deal. Photo: Ronald Zak/ASSOCIATED PRESS

That pact became a symbol of corruption in Egypt over charges that Egypt sold natural gas to Israel at below-market prices in exchange for kickbacks. In 2012, a former Egyptian oil minister, a former chairman of the state gas company and a prominent businessman were all sentenced to jail terms for squandering public funds in the deal. It also stirred opposition from Egyptians who remain skeptical about their country’s ties with Israel.

Egyptian officials have said they wouldn’t import gas from Israel until they resolved international arbitration cases stemming from the 2012 shutdown. But an Eastern Mediterranean Gas executive said the litigation can’t legally jeopardize the flow of gas. Israel’s energy minister Yuval Steinitz also said he doesn’t expect the Thai lawsuit to pose a significant obstacle.

Israel and Egypt now plan to test the pipeline this month, with commercially available gas flowing in January, according to Israel’s energy minister and an Egyptian energy executive.

“There were some bureaucratic delays, but I think most of them are already over by now,” Mr. Steinitz said.

An Egyptian security official took position on a sand dune during an operation in the northern Sinai Peninsula in 2012. Photo: AFP/Getty Images

The Israeli-Egyptian gas deal of 2018 was brokered with the help of the U.S. State Department and was meant to jump-start an energy partnership that had become bogged down with bureaucratic delays, security issues and litigation.

The Eastern Mediterranean Gas executive said the lawsuit would be “a headache” for the two countries’ gas partnership.

The lawsuit also highlights how the current and past gas deals with Israel have further cemented the control of Egypt’s powerful security services over key sections of the Egyptian economy.

The former head of Egypt’s powerful General Intelligence Service, Omar Suleiman, was involved in talks with the Thai company before its investment in the pipeline company, according to the legal complaint, seen by The Wall Street Journal.

—Felicia Schwartz in Tel Aviv contributed to this article

Write to Jared Malsin at jared.malsin@wsj.com
description: A $15 billion natural-gas deal between Israel and Egypt faces legal challenges and concerns about security threats from Islamic State, casting uncertainty over a pact meant to deepen ties between the two countries.
